title.value: Rethinking Teacher-Student Curriculum Learning through the Cooperative Mechanics of Experience
title.justification: The title is clearly stated at the beginning of the paper, along with author names and affiliations.
title.quote: Rethinking Teacher-Student Curriculum Learning through the Cooperative Mechanics of Experience

extractions.description: The paper proposes a data-centric perspective to analyze and enhance the Teacher-Student Curriculum Learning (TSCL) framework. It utilizes cooperative game theory to explore how the teacher influences the learning process by controlling the sequence and composition of experiences presented to a learner. The paper presents a novel foundation for understanding TSCL by demonstrating its equivalence to cooperative games and evaluating its mechanics through supervised learning, reinforcement learning, and classical games experiments.

type.justification: The paper involves theoretical exploration by proposing a new perspective using cooperative game theory in the context of TSCL rather than reporting experimental results or empirical analysis.
type.quote: we propose a data-centric perspective to analyze the underlying mechanics of the teacher-student interactions in TSCL.

name.justification: The paper focuses on Teacher-Student Curriculum Learning and seeks to explore and enhance this framework using cooperative game theory.
name.quote: Teacher-Student Curriculum Learning (TSCL) is a curriculum learning framework that draws inspiration from human cultural transmission and learning.

name.justification: The paper evaluates TSCL through experiments spanning supervised learning, reinforcement learning, and classical games, indicating a focus on reinforcement learning as a sub-research field.
name.quote: These experiments simulate ordered and unordered coalition formation processes and approximate the cooperative games we developed to describe TSCL. For every problem, we estimate units a priori value (e.g., Shapley or Nowak & Radzik values) and demonstrate that these a priori values, although expensive to compute (Deng & Papadimitriou, 1994), are useful proxies to find curricula.

name.justification: The paper discusses the evaluation of TSCL in the context of supervised learning as one of the experimental settings.
name.quote: To demonstrate the predictive power and range of problems where this game-theoretic and data-centric interpretation of TSCL applies, we build an experimental setting that evaluates the prospect of cooperation among units of experience in problems spanning supervised learning (SL), reinforcement learning (RL), and classical games (Sec. 5).

name.justification: The MNIST dataset is used in the experiments as a reference to conduct analyses concerning supervised learning.
name.quote: Example 3.1. For an analysis, we may define a unit of experience as the set of instances of class in a SL classification problem. For example, in the MNIST dataset (LeCun & Cortes, 2010), there may be ten units of experience, namely, classes ZERO, ONE, TWO, . . . , NINE.

referenced_paper_title.value: The MNIST database of handwritten digits
referenced_paper_title.justification: LeCun & Cortes, 2010 is likely the reference where MNIST dataset is explained which is a standard dataset referenced in multiple papers.
referenced_paper_title.quote: For example, in the MNIST dataset (LeCun & Cortes, 2010), there may be ten units of experience, namely, classes ZERO, ONE, TWO, . . . , NINE.

name.justification: The CIFAR-10 dataset is used in the experiments related to supervised learning, where class confusion is evaluated.
name.quote: We applied the same general procedure to CIFAR10 (Krizhevsky, 2009).

referenced_paper_title.value: Learning Multiple Layers of Features from Tiny Images
referenced_paper_title.justification: Krizhevsky, 2009 is the likely reference for the CIFAR-10 dataset based on standard citations for this dataset.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We applied the same general procedure to CIFAR10 (Krizhevsky, 2009).

name.justification: The M INIGRID dataset is used for experiments in the reinforcement learning paradigm as a gridworld environment suite.
name.quote: We investigate the M INIGRID -ROOMS (Chevalier-Boisvert et al., 2018) set of three environments, namely, T WO ROOMS, F OUR ROOMS, and S IX ROOMS for which it is folk knowledge that an optimal curriculum exists.

referenced_paper_title.justification: Chevalier-Boisvert et al., 2018 is likely the reference for the MINIGRID environments used in the experiments.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We investigate the M INIGRID -ROOMS (Chevalier-Boisvert et al., 2018) set of three environments, namely, T WO ROOMS, F OUR ROOMS, and S IX ROOMS

name.justification: PyTorch is mentioned as the deep learning library used to implement models and architectures involved in the experiments.
name.quote: All models and architectures are implemented with P YTORCH (Paszke et al., 2019).

referenced_paper_title.value: PyTorch: An imperative style, high-performance deep learning library
referenced_paper_title.justification: Paszke et al., 2019 is the standard reference for the PyTorch library as noted in the paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: All models and architectures are implemented with P YTORCH (Paszke et al., 2019).
